# Part 1: The Evolution

## Classical vs. Intelligent Systems

::: columns
::: {.column width="50%"}
**Deterministic**
![](images/deterministic.jpg){height="300" fig-align="center"}
*Predictable. Static.*
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
**Stochastic**
![](images/stochastic.jpg){height="300" fig-align="center"}
*Adaptive. Learning.*
:::
:::

::: notes
**Script:**
"Historically, SE was about building clockwork. If I turn gear A, gear B moves.
Today, we build systems like the Mars Rover. It encounters unknown terrain. We can't pre-program every reaction. It has to learn."
:::

## Why We Need AI

::: columns
::: {.column width="50%"}
![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/3/32/Muxviz_GlobalRisk.png){height="400"}
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
### The Complexity Gap
*   **Data Volume**: Terabytes/hour.
*   **Dimensionality**: Systems with 1000+ variables.
*   **Human Limits**: We cannot manually optimize these anymore.
:::
:::

::: notes
**Script:**
"Why can't we just write 'if-then' statements? Because modern systems look like this (point to network map). They are too complex for manual analysis."
:::

# Part 2: The Engineer's Definition

## Disentangling the Buzzwords

![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/1/1b/AI_hierarchy.svg){height="450" fig-align="center"}

::: notes
**Script:**
"Let's be precise.
**AI** is the machine acting smart.
**ML** is the algorithm learning from data.
**Deep Learning** is the neural network approach.
**Data Science** is the analysis of the logs."
:::

## The Engineering View

::: columns
::: {.column width="50%"}
### Classical
$$ y = f(x) $$
*We know the physics (F=ma).*
*We write the equation.*
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
### Machine Learning
$$ y \approx \hat{f}(x) $$
*We have the data points.*
*The computer finds the curve.*
:::
:::

![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/Linear_regression.svg/640px-Linear_regression.svg.png){height="300" fig-align="center"}

::: notes
**Script:**
"To an engineer, ML is just 'Function Approximation.'
We have a bunch of dots (data), and we ask the computer to draw the best line through them. That line becomes our law."
:::

# Part 3: The Lifecycle

## The V-Model and AI

![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/9/9b/Systems_Engineering_V_diagram.jpg){height="500" fig-align="center"}

::: notes
**Script:**
"This is the Holy Grail of SE: The V-Model. Think of it as the 'Map of Engineering.'

*   **The Basic V:** We go **down** into the details (Left) and then back **up** into the real world (Right).
*   **The AI Connection (Dual-Track):** AI is just a subsystem. The V-Model ensures the 'Smart' AI code actually integrates with the 'Real' hardware.
*   **The Requirement Shift:** Instead of writing rules (If-Then), we design the **Data**. We are engineering the environment the AI learns from.
*   **The Verification Gap:** We can't test every line of code in a neural network. Verification shifts from 'Does it match logic?' to 'Does it handle the statistical edge cases?'"
:::

## Astria: Digital Twin {.smaller}

:::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="50%"}
*   **The Physical Asset**: Autonomous drone with a gripper.
*   **The Digital Replica**: High-fidelity physics-based simulation.
*   **Systems Goal**: Testing contact physics and control logic virtually before risking expensive hardware on power lines.

## Rimless Wheel: Robustness {.smaller}

:::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="40%"}
*   **Systems Goal**: Walking that doesn't fall when the ground changes.
*   **Non-examples**: 
    *   Falling over (unstable).
    *   Tripping on uneven ground (fragile).
*   **Examples**:
    *   Steady rhythm on flat ground.
    *   **Robustness**: Recovering from uneven terrain.
:::

# Part 4: Live Case Study {background-color="#154734"}

## How AI Learns to Control

::: columns
::: {.column width="60%"}
![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Reinforcement_learning_diagram.svg/640px-Reinforcement_learning_diagram.svg.png){height="350"}
:::

::: {.column width="40%"}
**Reinforcement Learning**

1.  **Observe** state.
2.  **Take Action** (Voltage).
3.  **Get Reward** (+1 if upright).
:::
:::

::: notes
**Script:**
"We use Reinforcement Learning.
The AI tries random things. It fails. It learns. Eventually, it masters the physics."
:::

## Sim2Real: The Reality Check

::: columns
::: {.column style="width: 50%; text-align: center;"}
**Simulation**

![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/1/1b/Reinforcement_learning_diagram.svg){height="300"}

*Perfect Math*
:::

::: {.column style="width: 50%; text-align: center;"}
**Reality**

![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/f/f0/RotaryInvertedPendulum.JPG){height="300" style="filter: blur(1px) contrast(120%);"}

*Noise & Friction*
:::
:::

::: notes
**Script:**
"We train in simulation (perfect).
We deploy to reality (messy).
If the model overfits, the robot crashes. We need Robust Control."
:::

# Part 5: The Future

## The Black Box Problem

::: columns
::: {.column width="50%"}
### Classical Code
`IF speed > 50 THEN brake`
*(Traceable)*
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
### Neural Network
`0.23 * x1 + 0.99 * x2 ...`
*(Opaque)*
:::
:::

![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/Colored_neural_network.svg/640px-Colored_neural_network.svg.png){height="300" fig-align="center"}

::: notes
**Script:**
"Traditional code is readable.
Neural networks are millions of opaque numbers.
Traceability is a massive open problem in SE."
:::

## The Ethics of AI

![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/f/fd/Trolley_Problem.svg){height="400" fig-align="center"}

::: notes
**Script:**

As we build autonomous systems, we are engineering moral agents."
